poem:
"Celebrating Life Through Art"

Sketches bloom from fingertips,
Rooted in history's soil -
A portrait of liberation
Grasped in steadfast hands.
Visual voices sing tribute,
To strong woman, once bound,
Now free in canvas and color.
Competing, yet each a winner,
Carrying their prize in pigment.
In frames at Tate Britain,
We behold brave narratives -
Life's rich harvest, echoing.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Claudette Johnson’s art for Cotton Capital nominated for Turner prize Claudette Johnson has been nominated for this year’s Turner prize for her work, which includes a portrait of the African-American slavery abolitionist Sarah Parker Remond commissioned as part of the Guardian’s award-winning Cotton Capital series. Pio Abad, Johnson, Jasleen Kaur and Delaine Le Bas will compete for the £25,000 prize, while the nominated artists will each collect £10,000 as the prize returns to Tate Britain". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
